title: Not All Visitors are Bilingual: A Measurement Study of the Multilingual Web from an Accessibility Perspective

body.text: INTRODUCTION An estimated 2.2 billion people live with some form of visual impairment, and 90% of them reside in low-and middleincome countries [44]. As internet adoption grows in these regions, an increasing share of web content is created in languages other than English. Many of these languages use non-Latin writing systems such as Devanagari, Bengali, Arabic, or Thai and are often presented alongside English in mixed-language interfaces [28][29][30]. Popular screen readers like JAWS [2] and NVDA [7] still exhibit limited support for non-Latin scripts and often perform poorly when confronted with mixed languages [14,25,40,41]. These tools may misrender non-English words or produce unintelligible output, as has been documented with languages like Nepali [38]. The root of the problem lies in the inadequate usage of text alternatives [12,24] metadata such as lang attributes or image alt text, which screen readers use to process content appropriately. When such metadata is absent, incorrect, or inconsistent with the visible text, it creates a mismatch between the displayed content and what the assistive tool offers. This issue is compounded for scripts that require complex shaping or language-specific pronunciation models. For example, Apple's VoiceOver [11], the default screen reader on macOS and iOS devices, does not provide any support for languages such as Urdu, Amharic, or Burmese [11]. This lack of linguistic inclusivity is at odds with the principles laid out by the W3C Web Accessibility Initiative, which advocates for equal digital access regardless of language or ability [43]. Web accessibility research only marginally studies the intersection of multilingualism and assistive technology [17,18]. A key bottleneck in this area is the lack of data. Widely used datasets like Tranco [31] focus on popularity but do not provide any insight into the linguistic composition of websites. This limits the researchers' ability to measure the prevalence of multilingual content and to assess the accessibility landscape for speakers of less commonly supported languages. To bridge this gap, we introduce LangCrUX, a largescale dataset of 120,000 popular websites across 12 languages that primarily use non-Latin scripts. We construct LangCrUX by selecting high-traffic websites from the Chrome User Experience Report (CrUX) dataset, verifying language use via automated script detection and manual sampling, and through Puppeteer-based crawls routed via country-specific VPNs to capture localized versions of each site. We leverage LangCrUX to conduct the first large-scale analysis of multilingual web accessibility, focusing on how assistive technologies interact with real-world, multilingual web content. Our findings reveal that nearly 40% of websites in Bangladesh and India lack any accessibility text in the native language, despite having predominantly native-language visible content. More broadly, language-aware accessibility remains a widespread and under-addressed issue: many websites use non-descriptive, placeholder, or untranslated text (e.g., "file1, " "button, " or generic English terms) in critical accessibility elements like image alt text. These mismatches significantly reduce the utility of screen readers, which rely on metadata to convey meaningful information to users. We observe that current automated accessibility testing tools fail to detect these language inconsistencies, as they typically only evaluate the presence of accessibility hints. To address this gap, we propose and develop Kizuki 1 , a testing extension that identifies such mismatches and evaluates metadata based on alignment with the surrounding linguistic context, offering a more inclusive measure of accessibility. METHODOLOGY Our study investigates the accessibility of websites in non-Latin-script languages, focusing on linguistic diversity in underrepresented language communities. We collect LangCrUX, a dataset comprising websites with a high proportion of non-Latin-script content, combining data from the Chrome User Experience Report (CrUX) [8], custom web crawls using Puppeteer, and language metadata verification. Figure 1 visualizes our methodology, including dataset construction, language selection, and automated accessibility analysis. LangCrUX is released as an open-source dataset on GitHub. 2 Language and Country Selection Criteria: We begin with a pool of 26 widely spoken non-Latin-script languages, including Hindi, Bangla, Modern Standard Arabic, Tamil, Telugu, Mandarin Chinese, Urdu, Amharic, Russian, Marathi, and others [6]. Our goal is to identify a diverse, representative set of languages underrepresented in web accessibility research, particularly those using non-Latin writing systems. Language selection is guided by three main factors: script type (non-Latin), size of the global speaker base, and geographic and linguistic diversity. To ensure representativeness 1 named after the Japanese word for "awareness" 2 https://anonymous.4open.science/r/LangCrux-F68F Figure 2: Native language distribution in visible text for India and Israel in LangCrUX and sufficient data, we apply two strict inclusion criteria: 1) at least 10,000 websites with 50% or more visible textual content in the target language, and 2) inclusion in the CrUX datasetwhich provides user experience metrics from Chrome userswith sufficient traffic and performance data. Applying these filters results in a final set of 12 language-country pairs, each uniquely representing a distinct non-Latin-script language with a verifiable web presence. Because the initial pool alone did not yield enough languages that met these thresholds, we expanded the selection to include additional ones such as Hebrew, Sinhala, Greek, and Burmese. These were added to increase script and regional diversity while still satisfying our inclusion criteria. The selected countries, their corresponding languages, and approximate global speaker populations are China (Mandarin Chinese, 1.2 billion), India (Hindi, 609 million), Algeria (Modern Standard Arabic, 335 million), Bangladesh (Bangla, 284 million), Russia (Russian, 253 million), Japan (Japanese, 126 million), Egypt (Egyptian Arabic, 119 million), Hong Kong (Cantonese, 85.5 million), South Korea (Korean, 82 million), Thailand (Thai, 71 million), Greece (Greek, 13.5 million), and Israel (Hebrew, 9 million). Collectively, these 12 languages are spoken by over 3.19 billion people, representing about 39.5% of the global population. For languages spoken in multiple countries, such as Modern Standard Arabic, used in Algeria, Saudi Arabia, and Morocco, we select the country with the highest population of native speakers, in this case, Algeria. In multilingual countries like India, we include all major non-Latin-script languages with substantial speaker populations. However, only Hindi meets our data threshold; other widely spoken languages, such as Tamil and Telugu, do not meet the 10,000-website requirement and are excluded. Similar exclusions apply to Sinhala (Sri Lanka) and Georgian (Georgia), where websites with sufficient native-language content fell below the threshold despite initial inclusion. Website Selection: We use Google CrUX to identify and rank websites by real-world usage metrics. For each selected language-country pair, we extract the top 10,000 websites based on CrUX rankings, which reflect user engagement, load performance, and interaction quality. To validate language presence, we use a Unicode-based heuristic that matches visible text content against script-specific character ranges (e.g., Devanagari for Hindi, Hangul for Korean, and Cyrillic for Russian). For overlapping scripts, such as Arabic and Urdu, we include additional language-specific characters to improve precision. A website is retained if at least 50% of its visible textual content is in the target language. Websites that do not meet this threshold are excluded and replaced with the next-ranking candidate from the CrUX list. In cases where 10,000 qualifying websites could not be found among the top-ranked entries, we extended our search to lowerranked websites within the CrUX database to fulfill the quota. Figure 2 illustrates the distribution of visible content by language for two representative cases: Hindi websites in India and Hebrew websites in Israel. Data Collection: To extract accessibility-related features from the selected websites, we develop a web crawler using Puppeteer [9], which simulates web browsing conditions in a Chromium environment. Each website is visited programmatically, allowing us to capture network-level metadata, page structure, and accessibility indicators such as alternative text, ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes (which enhance the semantics of web elements for assistive technologies [1]), and declared language tags. To capture the localized experience of users in each country, we route all browser traffic through VPN servers physically hosted in the corresponding country. This step is critical for collecting region-specific versions of websites, as many sites dynamically serve content-including language settings, layout, or accessibility features-based on the user's IP location. Without VPN-based localization, web crawlers risk accessing global or English-dominant versions of websites that do not accurately reflect the intended user experience of native speakers. We use a combination of commercial VPN services, including ProtonVPN [10] and Hotspot Shield [23], to achieve broad geographic coverage. Since not all VPN providers have servers in every target country, we select the provider on a per-country basis to ensure reliable and consistent access from within national borders. Compared to crawling from generic cloud-hosted IPs, this approach offers a significantly more realistic vantage point, reducing the risk of content variation, redirection, or censorship artifacts that may otherwise skew accessibility analysis. Accessibility Element Selection Criteria: To identify accessibility elements where natural language plays a critical role, we follow a structured process based on the Lighthouse accessibility auditing framework [20]. Lighthouse evaluates a range of accessibility checks, each associated with specific HTML elements and best practices. Our goal is to select those elements for which the presence, clarity, and appropriateness of natural language directly influence accessibility outcomes. button-name document-title image-alt frame-title summary-name label input-image-alt select-name link-name input-button-name svg-img-alt object-alt Table 1: Web elements requiring natural language. We begin by examining the set of Lighthouse accessibility tests, which internally relies on the Axe-core accessibility engine [5]. For each test, we identify the corresponding HTML element it targets (e.g., ,

title: Comparison Between a State-of-the-Art Mechanical 3D Scoliosis Correction Protocol and the Schroth Exercise on Spinal Flexibility of Patients With Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

body.text:
Longitudinal traction; Mechanical 3D scoliosis correction; Rehabilitation; Schroth exercises; Spinal flexibility Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) refers to a 3-dimensional (3D) deviation of the spinal axis (in coronal, sagittal, and transverse planes), characterized by a Cobb angle > 10°a nd often accompanied by vertebral rotation. ][4][5] Early intervention can effectively halt the progression of scoliosis, prevent the occurrence of secondary musculoskeletal disorders, and reduce the surgical rate. 6,7 However, the effectiveness of the intervention depends on various factors, including the scoliotic curve flexibility, the magnitude of the Cobb angle, the segment of the curve along the spine, the number of vertebral body involved in the curve, and the curve pattern (eg, C-type, S-type, or double S-type). 8 he 3-point pressure system has been essential in conservative scoliosis treatment, guiding the design of some spinal orthoses. 9 Theoretically, the use of a 3-point pressure system or traction can effectively correct spinal deformity. However, the clinical application of the 3-point pressure principle has some limitations. The rigid curves, high thoracic curves, or large Cobb angles in some patients with AIS often reduce the effectiveness of the 3-point pressure system. 10,11 These limitations may be compensated by concurrently applying the traction in a sagittal plane along with the corrective pressures in the transverse plane to the spine. 12 The effect of combining the transverse 3-point force system with the longitudinal traction on patients with scoliosis has also remained unclear and merits further investigation. 

4][15][16] The brace treatment combines the coronal 3-point pressures/ forces and the transverse vertebral derotation force. 15 It can release the rigid soft tissue, reduce the scoliosis angle, improve surgical outcomes, and reduce the complications of surgical treatment. 13 However, the bracing treatment outcome can vary due to different factors, such as curve location, coronal deformity angular ratio value, and soft tissue characteristics. 14,17,18 For instance, when the number of constituent curvature vertebrae was less, the coronal deformity angular ratio value would increase, which may lead to a decrease in the corrective effectiveness. 19 1][22] The third scenario was that when the apex vertebra was located at T12, L1, L4, or L5, the transmission of the corrective force would be hindered by the ribs and iliac crests, which would adversely affect the effectiveness of the correction. 16,22,23 he fourth scenario was that in obese adolescents with scoliosis, the excessive soft tissue may also reduce the effectiveness of the 3D correction provided by the coronal 3-point pressure and transverse vertebral derotation force. 24 Furthermore, there were also some cases where the lateral forces could not work optimally for in-brace correction. It would be interesting to study if a device that is capable of simultaneously applying the 3D longitudinal traction forces and transverse corrective forces could provide better treatment outcomes for patients with these types of scoliosis. 

Spinal flexibility is an important indicator in AIS treatment and a reference of how much of the correction can be applied to an AIS patient's spine during both surgical 25 and conservative 26,27 treatments. Some recent studies have supported that spinal flexibility can predict the curve progression in patients with AIS. Specifically, patients with AIS with higher flexibility tend to experience less curve progression and better treatment outcomes. 28  has been primarily improved through physiotherapy scoliosis-specific exercise 29 or some spinal stretching exercises 30 in patients with AIS. However, the potential for motorized or automated systems to enhance spinal flexibility and alleviate scoliotic curvature has remained unclear and requires further exploration. To address the above-mentioned issues, this study proposed, developed, and applied a novel scoliosis correction system that generated both spinal longitudinal traction (based on the standard mechanical spinal traction protocol for managing low back pain) and transverse forces (based on the 3-point pressure system). We aimed to verify its efficacy in treating patients with AIS, especially in improving spinal flexibility. It is hypothesized that the developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction system and protocol could improve spinal flexibility immediately after 1 training session in patients with AIS with moderate scoliosis curves. Upon examining and verifying the feasibility, effects, and optimization with more future clinical trials, this novel treatment machine and protocol could provide a new approach for conservative treatments and further improve the treatment outcomes in patients with AIS. 

Methods

3D scoliosis correction system for delivering mechanical 3D scoliosis correction

We developed a novel 3D scoliosis correction system by modifying the traditional spinal traction equipment, which was originally designed for managing patients with low back pain. The apparatus consisted of a control platform, a longitudinal traction cable, a transverse 3-point correction component, and an axial rotational adjustment device on a treatment bed. 

The system operated by alternately applying the corrective forces of longitudinal traction, transverse 3-point forces, and derotational forces. It could be applied to correct various types of scoliotic curvature with different Cobb angles. The operation procedures included: (1) positioning the patient with AIS on the treatment bed in standing position; (2) using the electric controls to transit the patient into supine position on the treatment bed; (3) securing and linking the pelvic and trunk regions to the traction cable; (4) initiating the longitudinal traction with a force not exceeding 50% of the patient's body weight 31 ; (5) once the maximal longitudinal traction was reached, adjusting the location of the transverse 3-point pressure pads on both sides (applying the corrective forces to the apex and upper and lower end vertebrae of the curvature while simultaneously adjusting the height of the lateral force rods and the inflation of airbags on both sides of the bed to correct spinal rotation) 32 ; (6) entering a 30-minute cyclic scoliosis correction phase (via 15 repetitions of a cyclic alternating force application: longitudinal traction gradually decreased over 1 minute and 50 seconds, while the transverse 3-point correction component's airbags started to inflate, and when the traction force completely decreased to 0 N in the end of the 2 minutes, the lateral correction device's airbags started to inflate to their maximum values in 1 minute and 50 seconds, followed by deflation, at which point the longitudinal traction force started to increase again for a new cycle). The whole correction treatment was carried out under the principles of gradual force progress and safety, with an emergency button being provided for patients to immediately pause the mechanical correction procedure in any exceptional circumstances. 

Subjects

A total of 40 subjects, diagnosed with AIS by an orthopedic surgeon, participated in this study. All subjects were recruited from the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine Engineering at the affiliated teaching hospital of a university from August 2022 to March 2023. Inclusion criteria were (1) aged 10-18 years; (2) Cobb angle between 20°and 45°. Exclusion criteria included those who (1) received the treatments of braces or physiotherapy scoliosis-specific exercise within 6 months before this study; (2) had an intellectual impairment and inability to understand the instructions; (3) were unable to perform the sit and reach test. This study was approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of the hospital and was registered in the World Health Organization International Clinical Trials Registry Platform. All participants and guardians signed the written informed consent form before participating in this study. 

Measurement of Cobb angle

Each AIS participant's main Cobb angle was measured in this study. The entire spinal column of each subject was X-rayed in the anterior−posterior direction in a standing position. The Cobb method was used to measure the degree of scoliosis, which was performed by the same physiotherapist experienced in scoliosis assessment. 

Randomization, intervention allocation, and blinding

Subjects were assigned (in a 1:1 ratio) to the intervention group (IG) (receiving 30min mechanical 3D scoliosis correction treatment, 20 subjects) and exercise group (EG) (receiving 30min Schroth exercise treatment, 20 subjects) randomly. Randomization was performed using a table of random numbers generated by a blinded investigator with SPSS 16.00 a . Participants were assigned to their respective groups based on the enrolment order and corresponding random numbers. No stratification factors (such as sex, maturity level, or curve type) were used in the randomization process. All the investigators and the statistical analysts were blinded to group assignment, and all participants promised never to tell their interventions to anybody. 

Intervention Mechanical 3D scoliosis correction

Before receiving the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction, each participant's body height and weight were measured to calculate the required longitudinal traction force. Subsequently, participants wore a pelvic fixation belt and lay in a supine position on a traction bed (fig 1a). The traction bed was equipped with traction belts that could fix the participants under the participant's arms. Once the traction program began, the longitudinal traction force would be applied to the participant's spine at the level of the shoulder and pelvis. After this, the physical therapist manually adjusted the lateral force rod to apply the lateral corrective force. The applied lateral force was customized based on the participant's individual radiograph images and following the guideline of the 3-point pressure system, with the corrective force applied to the apex vertebra and the stabilizing/reactive forces applied to the end vertebrae. The magnitude of the lateral corrective force was adjusted based on the participant's pain perception, by providing the largest corrective force that each participant could tolerate. Each mechanical 3D scoliosis correction procedure lasted for approximately 30 minutes. During the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction, if participants experienced any pain, the therapist would adjust and reduce the lateral corrective force with reference to the pain threshold. All participants in the IG underwent a complete mechanical 3D scoliosis correction procedure. 33 

Schroth exercise

As shown in figure 1b, the participants in EG received a 30minute Schroth best practice (SBP) exercise session, guided by an SBP-certified physical therapist with more than 3 years of clinical experience. The SBP session mainly involved Physiologic exercises, instruction in the activities of daily living, 3D made easy program, "Power Schroth" exercises, rehabilitation of walking, and de-tethering exercises. 34 Each 30minute training session consisted of 5-minute derotation breathing training and 25-minute "Power Schroth" exercises, specifically featuring the frog on the pond, 50X, and muscle cylinder. Before the exercise session, the therapist evaluated each participant's scoliosis curve type based on the Lehnert-Schroth classification (3-or 4-curve) first, and then made the necessary adjustments to the detailed exercise elements and protocol for each participant accordingly. During the training process, the therapist would make adjustments to the exercise in real time based on the participants' physical condition, learning pace, and ability to perform the exercise. These adjustments included fine-tuning posture and positioning or modifying the focus of the session to align with the participant's individual needs. All adjustments adhered to the standardized procedures outlined in the SBP exercise manual. 34 

Outcome measure

All outcome measures were assessed at baseline and immediately after completing the intervention. The primary outcome measure was spinal flexibility, which was assessed using the sit and reach test, lateral bending test, and trunk rotation test. The secondary outcome measure was the changes in body height. 

Sit and reach test

The sit and reach test was used to evaluate the patient's forward bending (FB) flexibility. This test was conducted using the sit and reach tester, with the subject sitting on the floor with both legs straight and feet stepping on the vertical flat surface of the tester (by putting the heels together and toes apart for about 10-15cm). 35 Participants were then instructed to put their arms and hands straight, gradually flex the trunk to reach forward, and then use the fingertips of both hands to gently push the Vernier on the scale to make it slide forward until it could not continue to move. The participant should not have any sudden forward movement while performing this test. The inner plane of the stirrups of the test gauge was the 0 point, with the inward movements documented as the negative value and the forward movement documented as the positive value. The measurement was recorded in centimeters with 1 decimal point. The range of the tester was from À20.0 to +30.0 cm, with a "+" sign for positive and a "À" sign for negative values (figs 2a and b). 

Lateral bending test

To perform this test, participants were instructed to stand up straight with the feet together, keeping the body against a wall, and arms close to the sides of the body. 36 Participants were then instructed to lean the trunk to one side and keep the trunk close to the wall until reaching the limit. The 

Trunk rotation test

During the test, participants were instructed to sit in the center of a modified goniometer platform as designed by a previous study. 37 Participants were then instructed to hold their head in a neutral position with the chin tucked, flex the knees and hip joints for approximately 90°, and keep the arms straight forward. Then, the therapist provided the verbal instructions of "Keep your trunk upright," "Don't raise your shoulders," "Keep your arms straight," "Turn your head with hands," and "Don't lift your pelvis." Subjects were asked to keep their trunk at the maximal lateral rotation (to the left or right sides) for about 3 seconds (figs 2e and f). 

Body height assessment

The participant's body height was measured using an ultrasonic height tester. 38 

Data and statistical analysis

Data and statistical analyses were performed using the SPSS 16.00 a software package. The descriptive analysis results were reported using the mean § SD and median (interquartile range [IQR]) values. Categorical data were expressed as frequencies [n (%)]. The distribution normality of the measured variables was calculated using the Shapiro−Wilk test. According to the results, all the data conformed to the nonnormal distribution and thus were analyzed using nonparametric tests. Categorical variables, such as sex and curve type, were compared between the 2 groups using the Chi-square test. The Wilcoxon signedrank test was performed to compare the within-group results before and after the intervention (ie, pre-intervention vs post-intervention), whereas the Wilcoxon Mann-Whitney test was performed for between-group comparison (ie, IG vs EG). A P value of <.05 was determined as statistically significant. 

Results

Study population

As shown in figure 3, a total of 40 (out of 57) subjects with AIS met the inclusion/exclusion criteria and were included in the data analysis of this study. Of the excluded 17 subjects, 13 of them did not meet the inclusion criteria, and the rest of the 4 refused to participate in the study. No subject dropped out during the follow-up. 

The 40 eligible subjects with AIS (70.2%) were randomly assigned to the IG (n=20) or the EG (n=20). The results showed that the 2 groups were well-balanced at baseline, with no significant difference in the subject characteristics of age, sex, Cobb angle of the thoracic curve, or Cobb angle of the lumbar curve (table 1). 

Within-group comparison of spinal flexibility and body height: Before intervention versus after intervention

As shown in figure 4 and supplemental appendix S1 (available online only at http://www.archives-pmr.org/), significant improvements were observed in FB and left trunk rotation (LTR)/right trunk rotation (RTR) test results in participants of both IG and EG before and after the intervention (P≤.028). In addition, the IG participants further showed significant improvements in left lateral bending (LLB)/right lateral bending (RLB) test results (P≤.012), whereas the EG participants did not exhibit significant differences in neither the LLB (P=.623) nor the RLB (P=.147) test results. The IG participants also demonstrated a noteworthy increase in body height (P<.001), whereas no significant difference was observed in the EG participants for the body height (P=.784). 

Between-group comparison of spinal flexibility and body height: IG versus EG

As shown in figure 5 and table 2, although there was no significant difference between the 2 groups in the changes in spinal flexibility, there was a significantly larger increase in body height after the intervention (P<.001) in the IG participants (1.0 §0.6cm; 0.8 [0.7-1.2]) than that of the EG participants (À0.2 §0.5cm; À0.2 [À0.5 to 0.1]). 

Discussion

This study provided an innovative approach by modifying the traditional spinal traction devices into a novel digitalized 3D scoliosis correction system, which can be applied to implement a novel mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol for patients with AIS. 

The newly developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol has been identified as demonstrating potential improvements in the side-bending spinal flexibility of patients with AIS, after 1 session of the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction. The spinal flexibility was assessed in AIS participants by measuring the changes in the range of FB, lateral bending, and trunk rotation in sitting and standing positions. These measurements significantly improved with the implementation of the newly developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol. Such positive results were also supported by the significant increase in body height among the AIS participants, which might indicate the reduced Cobb angle in participants as suggested in a previous study. 38 However, it should be noted that these outcome measures were non-specific and could not exclude the movements that were generated by multiple joints and elements other than the spine. The observed positive result may not reject the possibility that the body was following more of the scoliosis pattern after the intervention. Future studies shall use some radiation-free imaging technologies, such as the 3D ultrasound assessment of scoliosis, 39 to verify this anticipation. 

The system to implement the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction was developed by combining the longitudinal spinal   32 The results of the current study have further supported that such a system could also be used to improve the spinal flexibility of patients with AIS nonsurgically. The advantages of the developed system were that it could improve spinal flexibility and correct scoliosis curvature, by enabling the simultaneous application of the longitudinal traction and the transverse 3-point corrective forces throughout the treatment process, whereas it might be challenging and difficult for the physical exercise to maintain such level of correction consistently. It should be noted that the developed system had alternate elongation and derotation phases, instead of simultaneous correction. This could not fulfill the need that a good correction design following the 3-point pressure system shall provide the correction force that covers all 3 planes simultaneously. Future attempts will be put on optimizing the device by integrating multiplanar corrective forces simultaneously. 

The results corroborated the finding that Schroth exercises can effectively improve the trunk FB flexibility of patients with scoliosis and further demonstrated that such exercise could improve the LTR/RTR ranges but not the LLB/ RLB ranges, which have not been reported previously. Lai et al 40 reported that the spinal deformities reduced the forward flexibility of the lumbar spine in patients with idiopathic scoliosis. A previous study has also applied the Schroth and suspension exercises in patients with scoliosis and observed significant differences in flexibility, strength, and balance abilities after the intervention. 41 However, only the sit and reach test was used to assess the FB flexibility of participants in that study. Jorgi c et al 42 also used the sit and reach test to evaluate the effect of the Schroth exercise and observed that the Schroth exercise could enhance motor function, lumbar extensor flexibility, and isometric Table 2 The between-group comparison of changes before and after intervention in AIS participants (n=40) 

IG (n=20) 1.9 §1.8; 1.6 (0.5-3.3) 

À1.1 §2.2; À1.0 (À1.9 to À0. endurance among children with idiopathic scoliosis. To our knowledge, none of the previous studies have investigated the changes in the range of lateral bending and rotation of the trunk in patients with AIS on completing the Schroth exercises. The results of the present study filled such a research gap and supported that a 30-minute Schroth exercise could also improve the LTR/RTR ranges but not for the LLB/RLB ranges in patients with AIS. 

The positive results and the innovative protocol of combining the longitudinal traction force, coronal 3-point pressure, and derotation force in 1 system might provide a new conservative scoliosis treatment. Most existing guidelines recommended that the criteria for determining the effectiveness of brace therapy were to maintain the current Cobb angle without progression or to reduce it by 5°-10°. 43 However, it has been a great challenge to achieve such Cobb angle reduction for moderate scoliosis, especially to sustain such reduction beyond the adolescent period, because the higher the Cobb angle, the higher the risk of progression in scoliosis patients. 44 The positive effect may be achieved by wearing a spinal brace in patients with AIS with moderate curvature (20°≤Cobb angle≤45°), depending on the type and location of scoliosis. However, it has been difficult to use bracing treatment to correct the severe curvature (Cobb angle>45°), due to the biomechanical principle that the elongating forces would be equal to the compressing forces longitudinally when the curvature reached an angle of 45°. This is also why most patients with scoliosis with severe curvature (Cobb angle>45°) were not prescribed with conservative treatments. It has been reported that the effect of simply applying the transverse 3-point pressure/force might be limited to correct severe scoliosis with a Cobb angle of > 53°. 17 Although a recent previous study has explored the possibility and reported positive results of using the bracing treatment together with the instrumented corrective exercise to correct the spinal deformity of patients with AIS, 45 the current pilot study further identified that it is also feasible (with preliminary effectiveness) to combine the longitudinal traction force, coronal 3-point pressure, and derotation force in one system to achieve the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction for patients with AIS. The developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol might be prescribed for patients for a period of time to improve their spinal flexibility and/or reduce their scoliosis curvature first, followed by the fitting of the spinal braces to maintain the achieved improvement of spinal flexibility and correction/ reduction of scoliosis curvature. This could expand the scope of conservative scoliosis treatments. It would also be interesting and worthwhile to explore these potential aspects and hypotheses in future studies. For example, in cases where the Cobb angle was larger than 20°or even 45°, the conventional application of applying the transverse or longitudinal forces alone may be of limited effectiveness. Future studies may consider exploring the potential benefits of using the mechanical 3D scoliosis correction as a preparatory treatment before the fitting of the brace, which may help broaden the scope of conservative scoliosis treatment. Further clinical research, with a focus on optimizing and improving the system and the protocol, is still needed to determine the optimal treatment duration, method of force application, and alternating force intervals, to provide a more scientific and effective treatment for patients with scoliosis. 

Study limitations

Several limitations must be acknowledged for this pilot study, with some findings that need to be interpreted with caution. First, this was a relatively small scale clinical study with a small sample size. This may lead to low statistical power and nonsignificant statistical results for the baseline demographics of the 2 subject groups, despite the noticeable between-group differences. Future studies will increase the sample size and consider matched analyses to address this issue. Second, only one session of the intervention was investigated, which may affect the generalization of its effectiveness in this study. Future studies will consider investigating and comparing the long-term effects and differences of the exercise on patient's spinal flexibility between the 2 interventions. Third, the developed digitalized 3D spinal correction machine had alternate elongation and derotation phases, instead of simultaneous correction. This could not fulfill the need that a good correction design after the 3-point pressure system shall provide correction force that covers all 3 planes simultaneously. Future attempts will be put on optimizing the device by integrating multiplanar corrective forces simultaneously. Fourth, this study mainly recruited patients aged between 10 and 18 years and did not collect information on the patient's maturity level. It should be noted that the maturity level and growth potential are more important than the actual chronological age when it comes to treatment response in patients with AIS. Future studies will consider incorporating these indicators to improve the selection of participants and enhance the robustness of study findings. The relation of the outcome to a specific maturity level will also be conducted in the future. Fifth, this study did not conduct a subtype analysis of how different curve types responded to treatment, which is crucial for a comprehensive evaluation. Future studies can perform such analyses to facilitate a comprehensive evaluation that can guide future clinical practice. Sixth, the intervention group participants were passively lying in the supine position, which unloaded the spine for approximately 30 minutes. This may relax the spine and contribute to the observed increase in body height. Future studies will include a new blank control group in which the participants keep the same lying position for 30 minutes, without activating the machine, to further verify the results. Seventh, although the intervention group participants were in the supine position, the control/exercise group participants were in the upright position. The upright position may increase the curve magnitude under the influence of gravity, compared to the supine lying position. This may further affect the interpretation of the observed difference in body height between the 2 groups. Future studies could further control the body position of different groups and adopt supine-based Schroth exercises, to ensure greater consistency and accuracy in assessing the intervention's effects. Eighth, the positive results from the sit and reach, lateral bending, and trunk rotation tests have suggested improvements in spinal flexibility after the interventions. However, it should be noted that these outcome measures were nonspecific and could not exclude the movements that were generated by multiple joints and elements other than the spine. The observed positive result may not reject the possibility that the body was following more of the scoliosis pattern after the intervention. Future studies should consider involving more specific outcome measures of spinal flexibility, such as the side-bending and fulcrum-bending tests, with validation from the imaging measurements. 27 inth, the observed improvements in testing scores may be due to the learning effect in participants. In addition to the randomization of participants that was adopted in the current study, it is also suggested to employ the blocking of the interventions in future studies to further address this issue. The spacing technique is also recommended to increase the duration of time interval between the baseline assessments, interventions, and the post-intervention assessments. More large and higher quality clinical studies with a long-term treatment will be conducted to verify the effectiveness of the developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol in improving scoliosis flexibility and reducing scoliosis curvature in patients with AIS. 

Conclusions

The newly developed mechanical 3D scoliosis correction protocol showed preliminary feasibility and effectiveness in instantly improving the side-bending spinal flexibility and the body height of patients with AIS, as assessed by measuring the changes in the range of FB, lateral bending, and trunk rotation. This protocol could provide a new conservative scoliosis treatment option, by combining the longitudinal traction force, coronal 3-point pressure, and derotation force in one digitalized system. However, further efforts are still needed to explore whether such treatment protocol could treat patients with scoliosis with special apex vertebra position, obesity, and large Cobb angle (eg, >45°), who are facing challenges in achieving satisfactory treatment outcomes/prognosis with the existing conventional conservative treatment options. Supplier a. SPSS, version, 16.00; IBM.

None.

title: Hungarian Qubit Assignment for Optimized Mapping of Quantum Circuits on Multi-Core Architectures

body.text:
I. INTRODUCTION

Q UANTUM computing has emerged as a groundbreaking paradigm with the potential to revolutionize various fields, such as cryptography, machine learning, and optimization [1]- [3], thanks to the use of quantum properties such as entanglement and superposition. 

Quantum computers [4] are currently constrained by a limited number of qubits. Even the most advanced quantum processors comprise only a few hundred qubits [5]. To unleash the total computational power and achieve universal fault tolerance, scaling up quantum computers while ensuring minimal increments in error rates becomes imperative. Nowadays, quantum computers are designed as single-chip processors, known as single-core quantum processors, containing all qubits within a single chip. This monolithic architecture encounters challenges in scalability due to the undesirable rise in qubit interactions, leading to issues like crosstalk [6]. To overcome these limitations, alternative approaches are sought, aiming to expand qubit counts and enhance scalability for future quantum systems. 

A feasible approach for scaling quantum computers is to go from a monolithic quantum computer to a multi-core ap-P. Escofet, E. Alarcón, and S. Abadal are with Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, and A. Ovide and C. G. Almudever are with Universitat Politècnica de València. 

Authors acknowledge support from the European Research Council (ERC) under GA 101042080 (WINC) and the European Innovation Council (EIC) Pathfinder scheme, GA 101099697 (QUADRATURE). 

EPR Pair Generator EPR Pair Generator

Fig. 1. Example of a four-core (rectangles) quantum computer with 20 qubits (circles) per core. Interacting qubits are depicted with a colour different than orange and linked to the qubit they are interacting with. On the left, an invalid assignment is depicted, while on the right, a valid assignment (with all interacting pairs of qubits assigned to the same core) is shown. 

proach [5], [7]- [11]. With the emergence of modular quantum computing architectures, new challenges arise, particularly in mapping quantum algorithms onto physical quantum devices. This compilation process is crucial for adapting a quantum algorithm to run efficiently on the desired quantum architecture, making it a central aspect of this cutting-edge technology. Figure 1 depicts a valid (right) and an invalid (left) mapping of qubits into cores for a four-core quantum architecture. Few multi-core oriented mapping algorithms [12]- [14] have been developed to address these challenges, with strong assumptions on the cores' constraints. Their optimality in mapping quantum algorithms across multiple cores has not been rigorously examined. We propose an alternative multicore mapping algorithm based on the observed limitations of current mapping techniques for multi-core architectures. It is designed to achieve fewer inter-core communications, facilitating improved scalability and performance. The performance of the proposed inter-core mapping algorithm is rigorously compared to existing state-of-the-art approaches. 

II. BACKGROUND AND RELATED WORK

To solve the scalability problem, several multi-core approaches have been proposed [5], [7]- [11]. The main goal is to increase the computational power of the quantum processor without increasing the crosstalk between qubits by having different quantum processors (or cores) connected via classical links (early stages) or by coherent quantum links (later stages). 

In multi-core architectures, many challenges arise, particularly in executing two-qubit gates involving qubits physically situated on different quantum processors, as illustrated in Figure 1. It is possible to perform two-qubit gates between distant qubits in different chips under specific practical conditions [15]. However, the fidelity of inter-chip links is lower compared to intra-chip links. 

Nonetheless, irrespective of the specific implementation approach, the overarching challenge lies in optimizing the number of non-local communications. This is essential for minimizing unnecessary actions, enhancing gate fidelity, and maximizing the efficiency of quantum computations. Various inter-core communications protocols to perform two-qubit gates exist, including remote gate operations and the transfer of quantum states followed by local gate executions. 

In the context of our paper, we focus on the multi-core architecture model proposed by Rodrigo et al. in [10]. This model suggests using a maximally entangled state, often called an EPR pair, as a foundational communications resource to facilitate the transmission of quantum states between cores. The communication protocol employed in this model, known as quantum teleportation, provides an efficient means to transfer quantum information between cores while leveraging classical communications. 

A. FGP-rOEE

This section reviews the inter-core mapping algorithm proposed in [12], called Fine Grained Partitioning (FGP-rOEE), which is one of the scarce algorithms proposed so far to solve the mapping problem for multi-core quantum computers. Other mapping algorithms, such as [13] and [14], use EPR pairs for remote operations apart from teleportation. 

The FGP-rOEE algorithm takes as inputs a quantum circuit with q qubits and an architecture with N cores, each one containing q N qubits. Two assumptions are made: i) The coupling map of each core is all-to-all; i.e., all qubits in a core have direct connections to one another, allowing the direct execution of a two-qubit gate if both qubits are located within the same core. ii) Cores are interconnected all-to-all, enabling the exchange of quantum states between any pair of cores. 

The algorithm's goal is to obtain a sequence of assignments of qubits to cores, one assignment per timeslice (the set of quantum gates that can be executed in parallel). The circuit is separated into timeslices, and for each of them, a valid assignment of qubits to cores is found. A valid assignment must have every pair of interacting qubits in the timeslice assigned to the same core, so no two-qubit gate involves qubits located in different cores. 

For a given timeslice t, FGP-rOEE computes the interaction graph of that timeslice, a graph with the qubits as nodes and an edge between two nodes if the qubits interact with each other in future timeslices. The edges are weighted, representing the immediacy of the interaction. These weights are called lookahead weights and are computed using Equation (1), where I(m, q i , q j ) = 1 if qubits q i and q j interact at timeslice m, and the exponential decay function is used so nearby timeslices have more impact on the look-ahead weights than latter ones. 

For qubits that interact exactly at timeslice t, a weight of infinity is set to the edges since, at that timeslice, they must be in the same core. 

A k-partitioning algorithm is then applied to the interaction graph, partitioning the graph into k disjoint subsets of nodes. 

For our case, k equals the number of cores N , and it is a requirement that all partitions have the exact same size, as cores have a fixed size, and we can only assign q N qubits into each core. Because of these requirements, the number of available k-partitioning algorithms is scarce. 

In [12], the use of the Overall Extreme Exchange (OEE) algorithm [16] is proposed. The OEE algorithm builds upon the Kernighan-Lin (KL) algorithm and expands its capabilities. In OEE, the process begins with an initial configuration of qubits, and a pair of qubits is selected for sequential exchange. This selection is based on optimizing the minimized exchange cost for the current exchange. If the exchange cost remains positive, further exchanges are performed in an attempt to improve the configuration. The algorithm terminates if the exchange cost becomes zero or negative, indicating no further improvement can be achieved. In [12], a variation of the OEE algorithm is proposed, the rOEE or relaxed Overall Extreme Exchange. rOEE also starts with an assignment and performs exchanges of nodes until a valid partition is reached (i.e. all interacting qubits are in the same partition). 

This procedure is repeated for every pair of timeslices, using the previous assignment of qubits to cores as input for the rOEE algorithm. With this, a path of valid assignments is found over the whole circuit. 

III. HUNGARIAN QUBIT ASSIGNMENT

In this section, we propose an alternative inter-core mapper to FGP-rOEE. Similar to FGP-rOEE, the Hungarian Qubit Assignment (HQA) describes how to assign qubits to cores in between timeslices and is generalized to map the whole algorithm. However, instead of distributing qubits into cores, this algorithm distributes two-qubit operations into cores, a much easier task than the former. As each two-qubit operation within a timeslice involves two distinct qubits, the algorithm's output will be a valid assignment for that particular timeslice. 

A. General Overview

We start with a valid assignment of qubits to cores for timeslice t. The following timeslice (t + 1) has a set of unfeasible two-qubit gates involving qubits that are currently located in different cores. This is depicted in Figure 1 (left), where we can see five unfeasible two-qubit operations for an example architecture of four cores. 

The qubits involved in the unfeasible two-qubit operations are then removed from the assignment and placed in an auxiliary vector of unassigned qubits. Now, the task is to assign each operation to a core with enough space to take in the qubits. For this assignment, we will construct a cost matrix using the cost function in Equation ( 2), which assigns a cost C t to each pair of unfeasible two-qubit operation op i and core c j based on how many non-local communications are needed to place both qubits involved in the operation q A , q B into the destination core c j (i.e. one if a qubit involved in the two-qubit gate is already placed in the core, two otherwise). 

The cost matrix is used to assign a single operation to each core. To do so, we use the Hungarian algorithm [17], a highly efficient linear assignment algorithm with polynomial time complexity (O(n 3 )). Its versatility, simple implementation, and robustness make it a favoured choice in various fields, especially when a quadratic algorithm is impractical. 

The goal of the assignment problem is to find the best way to assign a set of tasks (cores) to a group of resources (unfeasible two-qubit operations) while minimizing the total cost. By doing this, at each iteration, only one operation will be assigned to each core, ensuring the core's size is not exceeded. 

When an operation is assigned to a core, both qubits involved are placed in the free spaces of the core. Therefore, the number of free spaces in the core decreases by two every time an operation is assigned to it. Placing both qubits in each operation into the same core ensures all two-qubit gates will be feasible in the following timeslice. 

When having more operations than cores, the Hungarian algorithm only assigns one operation per core, so some operations will remain unassigned. A new cost matrix will be computed for those unassigned operations, considering the new free spaces of each core, setting a weight of infinity for those cores already full. By doing this, we ensure that no core exceeds its capacity and that the resulting assignment will be valid. Iteratively, the cost matrix is computed, and one twoqubit operation is assigned to each core with free space until all qubits are assigned to a core. 

Each core must contain an even number of qubits interacting in unfeasible two-qubit gates for this approach to work. Otherwise, when assigning operations into cores, there will be a pair of qubits left to assign and two cores with exactly one free space each, making it impossible to assign an operation to the core. An auxiliary two-qubit gate involving two noninteracting qubits from the cores with an odd number of qubits involved in unfeasible operations is created to solve this, ensuring that all cores contain an even number of free spaces and that all two-qubit operations will be allocated. 

B. Considering future qubit interactions

Future interactions of qubits can be added to the cost matrix to perform an assignment that further reduces the number of non-local communications. To this end, we quantify how much qubits interact in future timeslices using the same approach as in [12], described in Equation (1). In particular, the attraction force of a qubit q i to a core c j is computed as 

where J t (q i ′ , c j ) = 1 if qubit q i ′ is in core c j at timeslice t, and w t (q i , q i ′ ) is computed using Eq. ( 1). 

The new cost matrix is then computed using the costs given in Equation (5), where the number of non-local communications needed and the attraction forces are combined. Note that, as each operation op i involves two qubits (q A and q B ), the operation's attraction force to a core is the average attraction force of the involved qubits. 

The proposed approach cost function is completely tunable, allowing for more complex variations of the problem. For example, if not all cores are connected to each other, the number of non-local communications to move a qubit to a given core may be more than one. The cost function can be adapted to this case, and many others, leading to a robust and widely applicable inter-core mapping algorithm. 

IV. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION

In this section, we compare the state-of-the-art inter-core mapper (FGP-rOEE) and the proposed approach (HQA), using the number of inter-core communications as the evaluation metric (the lower, the better). For this evaluation, we will partition various quantum algorithms into modular architectures, varying the number of qubits and cores. The selected benchmarks encompass a wide variety of quantum algorithms, including Quantum Random Circuit (with varying two-qubit gate densities), GHZ State Preparation, Cuccaro Adder, Quantum Fourier Transform, Quantum Volume, and Grover's Algorithm. This diverse set of benchmarks ensures a comprehensive assessment of the mapping algorithms' performance across different quantum computation scenarios. 

Algorithms are implemented using OpenQL [18], as in [10]. They are divided into time slices and partitioned using both state-of-the-art and our proposed method. The number of non-local communications is calculated, and the ratio of our approach to the state-of-the-art indicates optimization (ratio > 1) or diminished performance (ratio < 1). For the HQA, the cost function considering future qubit interactions (defined in Equation ( 5)) is selected, as it achieves a lower number of communications than its counterpart (Equation ( 2)). Such comparison is depicted in Figure 2. No Attr / Attr Ratio Fig. 2. HQA communications with and without using the attraction force, mapped into an architecture with 16 qubits per core and as many cores as needed, depending on the number of qubits used (x-axis). A structured circuit (Cuccaro Adder) and an unstructured one (Random) have been selected to highlight the importance of the attraction force. The box plot depicts the Cuccaro Adder communications ratio with the two approaches. 

The performance of the mapping algorithms is assessed through two scalability approaches: one involves increasing the number of cores in a fixed-size architecture, while the other entails expanding the number of qubits in an architecture with a fixed number of cores. 

In Figure 3, we show the ratio of non-local communications needed when having a fixed-size circuit (120 qubits) and mapping it into a modular architecture with a varying number of cores. Note that the number of qubits per core is also conditioned on the number of cores of the architecture since the total number of qubits matches the circuit's size. 

Despite, for some cases, having a higher number of nonlocal communications (ratio < 1.0), HQA exhibits superior performance compared to FGP-rOEE, achieving improvements up to ∼ 3.4× and an overall average improvement of ∼ 1.3×. Fig. 3. FGP-rOEE and HQA non-local communications ratio for the selected benchmarks, when mapping the 120-qubits into different modular architectures. Each bar represents the number of cores in the architecture, and it is selected such that each core contains the same number of qubits and ensures an even number of qubits per core. This criterion is essential to ensure the feasibility of assigning two-qubit gates within the chosen core configuration. 

Figure 4 shows the number of non-local communications needed to map the selected benchmarking algorithms into a 10core architecture when increasing the total number of qubits and, therefore, the number of qubits per core. Fig. 4. FGP-rOEE and HQA non-local communications ratio for the selected benchmarks, mapped into a 10-core architecture, when increasing the total number of qubits in the architecture. 

It can be seen that, for both scaling approaches, the proposed algorithm usually outperforms the state-of-the-art mapping algorithm, obtaining a lower number of non-local communications, an essential aspect of multi-core quantum compilation. Unlike most benchmarks, the HQA performs worse than FGP-rOEE when mapping the GHZ circuit. We estimate this is due to the edge-case structure the GHZ circuit has, where one single qubit interacts with all other qubits sequentially. In such cases, a mapping algorithm that uses a partitioning approach instead of an assignment approach performs better. 

It is worth mentioning that the attraction force for HQA has been designed to match the information used in FGP-rOEE by using the same look-ahead weights. However, several lookahead functions are evaluated in [12], and the best-performing one is selected. Therefore, tuning the attraction force of the proposed approach has the potential to decrease the number of non-local communications even further. 

V. CONCLUSIONS

Modular approaches are envisioned to appear very soon in quantum computers, bringing new challenges in compiling quantum algorithms to be adapted to modular architectures. In this work, we have proposed an algorithm to distribute, along the circuit, each qubit to a partition so each twoqubit gate can be executed. The proposed algorithm produces assignments based on simplified premises than other modulararchitecture mappers, as based on the assignments of unfeasible two-qubit gates into cores, instead of partitioning the interaction graph, as it was done by [12]. By doing this, a lower number of non-local communications between cores is achieved, improving the mapping of the quantum algorithm. Moreover, the proposed algorithm is highly customizable, allowing for a different topology among cores (not only all-toall connectivity). A different definition of the attraction force of qubits to cores can be proposed, for this work, we have used the same information that FGP-rOEE use.
